awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research - HSI ATE Hub - Diversifying the ATE Program with Hispanic Serving Institutions using Culturally Inclusive Mentoring and ATE Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
Community Colleges enroll a higher percentage of Hispanic students than any other sector of higher education.  Moreover, U.S. institutions of higher education are experiencing a growth trajectory of Hispanic student enrollment, with more than 2.3 million students currently enrolled.  Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) are essential points of access because they enroll a majority of all Hispanic college students and nearly half of all HSIs are community colleges. This project will bridge two NSF initiatives: Mentor-Connect (M-C) (DUE-1204463 and DUE-1501183) and KickStarter (KS) (HRD-1450661). These initiatives support community and technical colleges in learning about funding opportunities in relevant STEM programs at the NSF, and mentor institutional teams (faculty and administrators) in developing their project ideas, crafting a proposal, and submitting to the program of interest. To date, these two programs have collectively served 32 HSIs in nine states, with student enrollments ranging from 400 to 40,000 and Hispanic enrollment percentages ranging from 27% to 97%.

This project will enable Mentor-Connect and KickStarter to work together to: 1) support three annual cohorts of four teams from Community College-HSIs (CC-HSIs) with a program that combines the expertise of the two initiatives; 2) support the cohorts with mentors who are experienced ATE PIs, and/or with HSI-relevant ATE resources; 3) collect data on the effectiveness of the bridging strategy and augmentation activities; and 4) assess the impact as a proof of concept model for the ATE program (or any NSF program) to become more ethnically and racially diverse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The HSI ATE Hub, a three-year collaborative research project, established a bridge between two successful programs: Mentor-Connect (DUE-1501183, 1840856) and KickStarter (HRD-1450661, 1929686). Mentor-Connect mentors 2-year college faculty to develop competitive proposals for the NSF Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Program, and KickStarter facilitates strategic STEM assessment and planning to drive competitive STEM proposal development at 2-year Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs).

The primary program goals for HSI ATE Hub are: build capacity and leadership at 2-year HSIs for developing competitive ATE proposals and elevate 2-year HSIs as drivers of economic success in their communities via technician education.

Strategies to accomplish these goals included: 1) providing two-tiered mentoring of KickStarter participants to leverage the strength of the STEM planning completed through KickStarter with ATE proposal development mentoring provided by Mentor-Connect; 2) community building that would connect HSI ATE grantees with one another for learning and sharing; and, 3) identify or develop and make readily accessible resources specific to two-year college HSIs to support their work in meeting the needs of Latinx students and crafting competitive ATE proposals to advance technician education programs at their colleges.

While providing valuable insights for developing and implementing mentoring programs, the first strategy did not achieve anticipated outcomes. For a variety of unforeseen reasons, the projected number of KickStarter participant colleges did not choose to transfer to Mentor-Connect to develop ATE proposals. Compared to a target number of 12 colleges, only 5  transferred to Mentor-Connect to develop NSF ATE proposals. Of those that transferred, 4 of 5, or 80% received NSF ATE grants during the timeframe of the project. Among the reasons cited for not transferring were the Mentor-Connect requirement that 2 STEM faculty participate to serve as Principal Investigators for the NSF ATE project proposal they would develop (faculty were not integral to Kickstarter work with colleges), COVID-19 disruptions, and the desire of some Kickstarter HSIs to pursue a newly-announced HSI funding initiative at NSF rather than ATE funding. In addition, the pool of Kickstarter participant colleges from which transfers were recruited was small, since Kickstarter worked with cohorts of only 5-6 colleges per year over the life of that project. 

The Mentor-Connect and KickStarter programs operated under different approaches. Primary differences included 1) cohort sizes (Mentor-Connect > 20 two-year colleges, both non-HSIs and some HSIs and KickStarter 5-6 HSIs); 2) one annual proposal submittal cycle (Mentor-Connect) vs. try until you succeed over multiple years (KickStarter); 3) Focus on mentoring for ATE proposal writing and developing faculty leadership (Mentor-Connect) versus focus on mentoring competitive proposal writing across multiple NSF programs and developing institutional leadership through strategic STEM assessment and planning. 

Two other project strategies proved successful. Measurable positive impacts are resulting from curating HSI-specific resources and providing faculty development designed to guide use of the resources and broaden educator understanding to enable them to adjust to the changing student demographics in positive ways. One professional development webinar in particular, Culturally Responsive Instruction in HSIs: Specific Instructional Strategies that Work, featuring Melissa Salazar, CEO and founder of ESCALA Educational Services, Inc., sparked great interest as a beneficial instructional method for community college technician educators. Even with COVID-19, 170 educators registered and 96 attended the live webinar in April 2020, which increased awareness of Culturally Responsive Instruction and provided tools for immediate use. Evaluation was overwhelmingly positive. The webinar recording and presentation materials are available in the HSI ATE Hub Repository and Microsite https://atecentral.net/msites/atehsihub/home. The HSI ATE Hub Repository, featuring over 38 resources, has posted >1725 views, with particular interest in resources that feature culturally responsive practices.

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2022
Modified by: Elaine L Craft
